Deploying &productname; on &caasp;
yes
&readmefirst;
&productname; supports deployment on &caasp;. &caasp; is an enterprise-class container management solution that enables IT and DevOps professionals to more easily deploy, manage, and scale container-based applications and services. It includes &kube; to automate lifecycle management of modern applications, and surrounding technologies that enrich Kubernetes and make the platform itself easy to operate. As a result, enterprises that use &caasp; can reduce application delivery cycle times and improve business agility. This chapter describes the steps to prepare a &productname; deployment on &caasp;. See
for more information on &caasp;.
Prerequisites
The following are required to deploy and use &productname; on &caasp;:
Access to one of the following platforms to deploy &caasp;:
&suse; OpenStack Cloud 8
&vmware; VMware ESXi 6.7.0.20000
Bare Metal x86_64
A management workstation, which is used to deploy and control a &caasp; cluster, that is capable of running skuba (see for installation instructions). The management workstation can be a regular desktop workstation or laptop running &sle; 15 SP1 or later.
&cfcli-prereq; &kubectl-prereq; &jq-prereq; &curl-prereq; &sed-prereq;
&min-deploy-note;
Creating a &caasp; Cluster
When creating a &caasp; cluster, take note of the following general guidelines to ensure there are sufficient resources available to run a &productname; deployment:
Minimum 2.3 GHz processor
2 vCPU per physical core
4 GB RAM per vCPU
Worker nodes need a minimum of 4 vCPU and 16 GB RAM
As a minimum, a &productname; deployment with a basic workload will require:
1 master node
vCPU: 2
RAM: 8 GB
Storage: 60 GB (SSD)
2 worker nodes. Each node configured with:
(v)CPU: 4
RAM: 16 GB
Storage: 100 GB
Persistent storage: 40 GB
For steps to deploy a &caasp; cluster, refer to the &caasp; Deployment Guide at
When proceeding through the instructions, take note of the following to ensure the &caasp; cluster is suitable for a deployment of &productname;:
At the cluster initialization step, do not use the --strict-capability-defaults option when running
&prompt.user;skuba cluster init

Storage Class
&productname; requires a persistent storage class to store persistent data inside a persistent volume (PV). When a PV is provisioned, the storage class' provisioner determines the volume plugin used. Create a storage class using a provisioner (see ) that fits your storage strategy. Examples of provisioners include:
&ses; (see )
If you are using &ses; you must copy the Ceph admin secret to the scf namespaces used by &productname;:
&prompt.user;kubectl get secret ceph-secret-admin --output json --namespace default | \ sed's/"namespace": "default"/"namespace": "scf"/' | kubectl create --filename -
Network File System (see
By default &productname; assumes your storage class is named persistent. Examples in this guide follow this assumption. If your storage class uses a different name, adjust the kube.storage_class.persistent value in your configuration file.

Add the &kube; Charts Repository
Download the &suse; &kube; charts repository with &helm;:
&prompt.user;helm repo add suse https://kubernetes-charts.suse.com/
You may replace the example suse name with any name. Verify with helm:
&prompt.user;helm repo list NAME URL stable https://kubernetes-charts.storage.googleapis.com local http://127.0.0.1:8879/charts suse https://kubernetes-charts.suse.com/

Expanding Capacity of a ∩ Deployment on &susecaaspreg;
If the current capacity of your ∩ deployment is insufficient for your workloads, you can expand the capacity using the procedure in this section.
These instructions assume you have followed the procedure in and have a running ∩ deployment on &susecaaspreg;.
Add additional nodes to your &susecaaspreg; cluster as described in .
Verify the new nodes are in a Ready state before proceeding.
&prompt.user;kubectl get nodes
Add or update the following in your scf-config-values.yaml file to increase the number of diego-cell in your ∩ deployment. Replace the example value with the number required by your workflow.
sizing: diego_cell: count: 4
Perform a helm upgrade to apply the change.
&prompt.user;helm upgrade susecf-scf suse/cf \ --values scf-config-values.yaml \ --version &kubecf_chart;
Monitor progress of the additional diego-cell pods:
&prompt.user;watch --color 'kubectl get pods --namespace scf'
